Based on my search results, I found information about the real story that inspired George Orwell to write Animal Farm, specifically regarding the scene with a boy whipping a cart horse.

George Orwell witnessed "a little boy, perhaps ten years old, driving a huge cart-horse along a narrow path, whipping it whenever it tried to turn. It struck me that if only such animals became aware of their strength we should have no power over them." This real-life incident became the inspiration for Animal Farm.

In the preface to Animal Farm, Orwell described this as the source of the idea for setting the book on a farm, explaining that this observation made him realize "that men exploit animals in much the same way as the rich exploit the proletariat."(no content)It is assumed that Orwell got the basic idea for Animal Farm from seeing this young boy whipping the cart horse, and Orwell was partly inspired to write the book after seeing a young boy whipping a cart horse.(no content)It is believed that he was inspired to write Animal Farm after he had watched a man mercilessly whip a horse.(no content)Orwell wrote about this incident in his preface to the Ukrainian edition of Animal Farm in 1947, where he explained how this real-life observation of animal exploitation sparked the central idea for his allegorical novel about revolution and totalitarianism.

The cart horse being whipped by the young boy directly inspired the character of Boxer in Animal Farm - the loyal, hardworking cart horse who is eventually betrayed and sent to the knacker's yard despite his years of faithful service to the farm.
